title: Before 24 July 2020, will it be officially announced that the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics and/or Paralympics will be postponed, canceled, and/or relocated?
preds:
In the present circumstances and based on the information provided by the WHO today, the IOC President and the Prime Minister of Japan have concluded that the Games of the XXXII Olympiad in Tokyo must be rescheduled to a date beyond 2020 but not later than summer 2021.
https://www.olympic.org/news/joint-statement-from-the-international-olympic-committee-and-the-tokyo-2020-organising-committee
It's confirmed and the question isn't closed yet so I might as well make this final update https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/olympics/52020134

This is resolved :  https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/olympics/52020134 The Tokyo 2020 Olympic and Paralympic Games have been postponed until next year because of the worldwide coronavirus pandemic. The event, due to begin on 24 July, will now take place "no later than summer 2021". "I proposed to postpone for a year and [IOC] president Thomas Bach responded with 100% agreement," Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said. The event will still be called Tokyo 2020 despite taking place in 2021.
Update following the announcement from Olympic Committee member.

Armour, N. (2020). USOPC calls for postponement of Tokyo Olympics until IOC can ensure conditions are safe. USA Today. Olympics. March 23, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2020/03/23/tokyo-olympics-usopc-calls-postponement/2904370001/ The move comes hours after longtime IOC member Dick Pound told USA TODAY Sports that the Games would be postponed. The IOC had said Sunday it would make a decision within the next four weeks, but it has made no official announcement.
It’s all but confirmed. How ever learned from a previous question that very little is 100%  https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/athletics/52002474
Planning needs to be made accordingly and it would be irresponsible to take so long in the decision.
More historically-relevant countries are stepping-down due to covid-19 potential exposure to their athletes.

I found out, Minutes after updating my forecast, that Canada has withdrawn from the Olympics.
That sensible action has change my opinion and,  as a result, my forecast.

After the weekend's stats, I'm blown away by the devastating effect COVID is having countries and communities. 
I wonder if the best-case scenario would be a postponement. 
I'm less optimistic than I was on Friday.

There seems to be no chance of gatherings of this size happening within the next few months, and the decision for the Olympics/Paralympics will have to be made within those months. The size of the gathering even without attending fans is so large that accommodations will not work, so I believe they will certainly be canceled completely or postponed (though not simply relocated).

the go/no-go point will be long before the date of the start of the games and given the outlook at the moment, the idea of people from all over the world suddenly travelling en masse, meeting in one location, mingle, socialise then all leave to return home and potentially carry the virus is unthinkable. The precautionary principle will prevail and it will be posponed for a year.
Games postponed until 2021.Just off the wire.
Reporting citing inside info from IOC member Dick Pound

It's outright being reported that the Olympics are being delayed, but technically there's no word on the Paralympics (I'd say the probability is more like 0.5% that it's just the Olympics but I only have integer values) https://twitter.com/usatodaysports/status/1242140945396662273

Cancellation looking increasingly likely, adjusting forecast accordingly: https://www.forbes.com/sites/isabeltogoh/2020/03/23/japans-prime-minister-hints-olympics-will-be-postponed-due-to-coronavirus/#45e21321af70
As major countries start pulling out of the Olympic Games, and with no signs of Covid-19 slowing down anytime soon, it’s almost impossible to imagine these events happening as planned.

In my first forecasts, I stated that there was no chance that the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics would be cancelled, postponed or relocated.  I provided an explanation in my forecast on March 5, 2020.  The WHO declared COVID-19 to be a pandemic on March 11, 2020.  Since then, much has changed around the world. Canada and Australia have announced that they will not send athletes to the Summer Olympic games this year.  I expect other countries to follow suit.  The International Olympic Committee (IOC) said that they will not cancel the games but they are considering postponing them.  No one has an interest in cancelling the games due to the amount of money that has been spent on them so far. Sources:
https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/22/americas/canada-no-athletes-tokyo-olympics/index.html https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/22/world/olympics-coronavirus-tokyo-postpone/index.html

https://apnews.com/b7b71576eddb82422929f19d7fb32f44
A virus is very small and the gritted teeth of the forced smile on a prime minister are no barrier to it.   Abe has been asserting that all shall be well and all shall be well and all manner of things shall be well, but the IOC will not wish to run the Games with no athletes, even if they were okay with no spectators. There is no particular reason it should take them four weeks to sort this out, so the announced time frame is presumably just to save a bit of face for the Japanese government.   Awfully nice of them.

Canada has pulled out of the games today, and the world athletics body is also calling for postponement. As athletics is one of the central events of the Olympics, I think these recent factors point towards postponing the Games, if not abandoning the 2020 Games entirely.
Another link indicating postponement is likely. http://www.globalconstructionreview.com/news/olympic-body-mulls-delay-tokyo-2020-pandemic-escal/

Increasing looks like this will be postponed as the peak of the Corona virus will still be ongoing or only just have abated by the time their are meant to go ahead. This is the path of least resistance as the contracts underpinning the organisation of the games apparently allow this.
It's done. Canada is the first to pull out, but as the IOC delays the decision more countries will pull out. Games will slip to 2021.

Updating figures, as per last forecast, cannot see the games going ahead, there is just too much going on, teams and athletes need to prepare and might even fall ill, airlines and airports are not going to be ready, there is no vaccine in place.  It would be great if it did, but the harsh reality is it will not
Updating to reflect Canada not sending their athletes.

Canada not sending a team and Australia tell their squad to prepare for 2021.  The IOC are still adamant. Although if you look at the detail, they have said cancellation isn’t an option. I may be overplaying the semantics of words but cancellation is not a postponement.  Think the decision will be taken out of their hands by the competitions over the next week.  https://www.skysports.com/share/11962146

Stronger and stronger voices from within the sporting community against holding the Olympics this Summer. Canada has decided not to participate: https://olympic.ca/press/team-canada-will-not-send-athletes-to-games-in-summer-2020-due-to-covid-19-risks/

As Paralympics are held after Olympics, small chance only the Olympics will be impacted (i.e. postponed, canceled, or relocated).
Very small chance the Paralympics will be impacted but not the Olympics. Perhaps a small chance both will proceed but with a reduced scope (e.g. no teams sports, quarantined athletes only)

With general calls to postpone Olympics for athletes and Japanese officials expressing more of a willingness to postpone, updated to reflect higher likelihood of postponement. I could still see Olympics moved to after Paralympics

According to article linked below, Canada will not send athletes to Tokyo Olympics and calls for the games to be postponed for 1 year.  This makes it even more likely the games will be postponed. https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/22/americas/canada-no-athletes-tokyo-olympics/index.html

Failure to respond when needed has increased the risk of cancellation. Only chance for the games to continue as scheduled is if outcome of the efforts to contain have better than expected results.

the torch was passed but it will not happen

I keep seesawing back and forth, if the call was made right now, it would be cancelled. 
What we're trying to predict is if the world will be in a safer space in three months time in an environment that lacks consistency and with nothing that is historically similar. 
My feeling is that every COVID challenge we undertake here is underpinned with a large dose of conjecture.  So, for now, I'm going to keep my optimistic forecast.

Probability of delay increasing, but it could run its course to allow an Olympics without spectators during the summer.  That in itself would be a boon to the world if everyone were engaging in social isolation.

Reasons that it will be canceled/postponed/relocated:
- Other major sporting events have canceled/postponed
- Qualifying events have been canceled/postponed
- Athletes have not been able to train fully to prepare
- Some countries may not be able to travel to Japan due to coronavirus, particularly those in southern hemisphere
- Some athletic programs have petitioned not to go (USA Track and Field, USA Swimming) Reasons it won't:
- Japan would lose a lot of money
- International Olympic Committee President seems intent on going as planned
- Japan's coronavirus count is low, although this could be due to low number of testing, so actual case could be worse
- Could have Olympics with no spectators, but Japan would lose out on tourist revenue
- Could serve as an uplifting and hopeful event in a global time of despair Crowd: 2, 1, 91, 6 "Thomas Bach, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said in an interview Thursday [3/19] that the Games would not be canceled. And while he left open the possibility of postponing them, he said a decision did not have to be made soon." [1] 
"Until recently, their public statements reflected a show-must-go-on mentality, but within the last two weeks, cracks have started to appear." [1]
"“This time, it doesn’t make sense if others cannot attend from other countries, even if Japan alone will become all right,” Mr. Aso [Japanese finance minister] said." [1]
"In a poll released Monday [3/16] by Kyodo News, a Japanese news service, close to 70 percent of respondents said they did not expect the Tokyo Games to go on as scheduled." [1]
"Mr. Abe and Mr. Bach have both alluded to the fact that the Games could have the power to bring people together and help the world heal after the horrors of the pandemic." [1]
"In a conference call on Wednesday [3/18], IOC President Thomas Bach got support for holding course, but is also getting push back from athletes who can’t train, are confused about the qualification process, and worry about their health. Critics are also complaining about the unfairness of qualifying, which might give some athletes advantages over others." [2]
"Though the 1916 Summer Olympics were canceled due to the onset of WWI, and both the Summer Olympics of 1940 and 1944 were axed due to WWII, scrapping an Olympics in peacetime would be unprecedented." [3]
Some athletes have yet to qualify. Those needing to improve their rankings could miss out because many qualification events have been rescheduled. Baseball's final qualifying event, for example, scheduled to take place in Taiwan, has been moved from April to June." [3]
"Japan’s Olympic minister, Seiko Hashimoto, said it was “impossible” that the Games would be delayed. Then on Monday [3/16], Shinzo Abe, Japan’s prime minister, said he had secured support from the leaders of the G-7 to hold the Tokyo Olympics and Paralympics "in their complete form." [4]
"He noted Tuesday [3/17] that just 57 percent of the athletes are already qualified for the Games, meaning nearly half the places still need to be filled. “The IOC will work with the international federations to make any necessary and practical adaptations to their respective qualification systems for Tokyo 2020,” Bach said, suggesting that selections will be made based on existing rankings." In a showdown over public safety, the organizers of the Tokyo Olympics are facing a remarkable groundswell of criticism and pushback from their own athletes, fans and national Olympic officials, who are increasingly and unusually vocal in calling for a postponement. On Saturday, U.S.A. Track & Field added its voice to the list of sports bodies asking for the Games to be delayed. One of the biggest cracks in the usual solidarity behind the Games came Friday when the U.S.A. Swimming, which governs the sport in the United States and regularly produces stars at the Games like Katie Ledecky and Simone Manuel, called for a postponement because of the growing obstacles to training as a result of practical restrictions imposed by the virus.
Those two sports typically account for the most medals won by the United States.

"Postponed, cancelled and/or relocated" is broad enough to be likely. The disruption to training and travel plans alone leaves us questioning what countries can/will send representatives and how competitive these games ultimately will be if held on 24 July.

Because of the governments use of the coronavirus "crisis" to increase controls of the private means of production. They need people to be fearful to obtain their consent to submit to authority.  Canceling or postponing the games serves that purpose.

The most significant article yet, A Japanese committee official has broken ranks to call for it to be cancelled.  It does seem inevitable now.  The only reason my no is still at a generous 12% is they may be stubborn and wait 2/3 months before calling it off. A small hope that a "white swan" event happens and kills the virus leaves a 5% chance that the world will go back to normal before July.

I believe that Japan is currently under-testing it’s population and that will lead to a delayed recognization of what is a massive problem for all developed countries and ultimately a postponement or cancellation of the games prior to July 24th.

The Olympic committee has been critical of Japan’s attempt to keep the 2020 games and even the Japanese conversation has softened in recent days from “it will go on” to something more like “we will find the best option.” There are no events for athletes to polish and train at, so even if the organizers were truly stubborn, the Olympics would be an embarrassing flop if they went on as planned. I think it’s taking a long time to come to this decision based on the sink cost fallacy— Japan’s National conversation about the 2020 Olympics has been omnipresent all the time that I have lived here (5years). Once the decision is announced, Japan will probably begin to do a better job regarding Covid-19. General public opinion here is that the government is downplaying it because they had wanted to preserve the Olympics. That, and Japan’s lack of a CDC (meaning bureaucrats were responsible for assessing the risks of Covid-19, not an informed panel of experts) led to digging of heels in on the Olympics for longer than it should have been. But Japan is very sensitive to their national reputation and the criticism that attempting to keep the 2020 Olympics is irresponsible will probably make it easier for the government to save face about changing their direction.
Both will be either delayed or cancelled as there is very little time for worldwide athletes to practice or qualify with the Covid19 still spreading and at an upward trend worldwide.
There's no way around it. Who wants to go anyway?

With the virus taking hold, I believe the games will get cancelled/postponed. However due to the weight of history and how many olympics have happened despite bad world affairs, I think there's a realm in which competitors will compete in some events that are more solitary in nature (races, lifting, etc) - I see paralympic games requiring more person-person interactions and could slightly cause them to get cancelled with the main olympics undergoing some version of social distancing but still enabling track and field events.
Continuing the move towards both being postponed (or cancelled etc), since it seems there is more pressure there (based off a BBC News report) for a postponement.

"Japanese Olympic Committee (JOC) board member Kaori Yamaguchi has called for the Tokyo Olympics to be postponed because athletes are unable to prepare adequately as a result of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, she told the Nikkei newspaper." https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-outbreak-03-19-20-intl-hnk/h_df09a545c59749bf85069a58d10becbf

Even if Covid-19 cases decrease in specific geographies by late June/early July the likelihood that it is still active in many others. As such, the risk of re-sparking the pandemic by bringing athletes, spectators, and press from so many nations together is too high to justify.
It appears that the olympic comittee is kicking the can down the road. Keep that up for another few weeks and the decision is effectively made.

Japan cannot afford to risk thousands of athletes bringing more disease. Also, the spectacle of empty stadiums would look very bad. I’m sceptical that anywhere else could stage a worthwhile games at this late stage, so my view is that they will be postponed until next year.

both because of corona virus may be at his highest infection rate.

Unless there is some sort of vaccine, or better, cure, the only way the games can be played is if there is some way to put space between everyone, which is doubtful, especially for games where teams of players play, like basketball.  Perhaps isolating the athletes for two weeks before hand?  But then there are all the other people necessary to officiate and broadcast the games, as well as feed and service all these athletes, they would need to be isolated too. Plus, part of the spectacle is having the huge crowds participating, and there is no way to do that, there can be no audience, as that risks infecting the players.  So I think both are postponed.

Japan is handling the cases well, but it is still ongoing globally.  Bringing Olympians, trainers, press, and spectators in from countries who are still in the midst of COVID19 response alongside those who may not have been exposed would be far too risky.

It is unlikely for only 1 of the Games to be postponed/cancelled considering 1 month between them. Hence putting small probability there. However, given that Olympics start 1 month earlier, am rating that slightly higher. Arguments for continuing
- Both IOC and Japan want it to be held this year. IOC for the broadcasting money, Japan as it has already invested into this. This could indicate that holding events with limited audience is something both are prepared for. Arguments for cancellation
- While Olympics has only ever been cancelled for wartime, wartime comparisons are being thrown around right now.
- Qualifiers are getting cancelled/postponed for both events, and current lockdowns are making it difficult to determine when they can be held.
   - Mar 18 - Only 57% of people set to attend that games has qualified. https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/51943083
   - List of cancelled/postponed Paralympic events: https://www.paralympic.org/news/information-para-athletes-and-ipc-members-regarding-coronavirus
- Japan is already suggesting that Games can be postponed within 2020.
- Looking at the trajectory of new cases and deaths, I think it will take more than 2-3 months to peak. Until then, the growth will be exponential and that will put pressure on the cancellations. Conclusion: I fully believe that at this point, IOC and Japan fully believe that the Games will go ahead. However, I also think they will change their mind in the next few months as worldwide cases continue to increase.

We judge the future based on our perceptions today. And today  COVID-19 is a scary beast that forces social distancing, closing schools, travel bans and economy downturn. According to WHO and CDC (and in our minds), the whole world is on fire, even countries like China and South Korea, which apparently got it under control (though may lose it). IOC insistence on Olympic Games seems irresponsible and careless Fast forward 4 months. Imagine - everywhere there was an economic downturn. Restaurants have been closed, sport events cancelled. Unemployment soared, markets crashed. Doom and gloom. But a lot of countries (even Italy), with extreme measures, seemingly took the epidemics under control. Yes, there were (tens) thousands of deaths, the health systems overwhelmed... People made sacrifices and it became "better". People discovered that while it is scary on TV and internet, most people didn't get infected, but suffered economically, emotionally nevertheless. Yes, it came to full force to the Southern Hemisphere (with winter there) and now is worsening in Africa and Latin America. But there (some, most promising, which means money for support) athletes adapted, moved to train to Northern Hemisphere, to Japan, South Korea, China (with acclimatization in time as a bonus). People want a relief from all this. And IOC makes a decision - to go ahead with the Olympics (with potential no public on stadiums). Yes, some athletes may miss it. But it looks fair as the most trained for this all previous years and any disruption/postponing looks Unfair to them. What looked as reckless in March now, in July, seems to be bold, inspiring. To hold the Games against all odds. In their future decision not to postpone, IOC cited … history of the Spanish flu: they reminded that it was the SECOND wave of Spanish flu that killed most people.  The Spanish flu most probably started in late 1917, maybe also in China (the Chinese dispute that). It led to some deaths and spread to North America and Europe. Then it almost disappeared after the season. But it came back in late 1918 (possibly in mutated form) and became a devastating pandemic. So postponed Games can be held under even worse conditions. PS: As a contrarian, I was inspired by excellent analysis of @sevedb and by @Anneinak and @bobrown who switched their position. PPS: Or maybe, being in a scientist, I just believe in all conquering science too much. Or anchored in my numbers from the beginning (100% "No").
Update: Irrespective of what officials are saying, there is more and more evidence for postponement among both participants and organizing committees

First, getting rid of the "Olympic Games only" and "Paralympic Games only" options with 2% each. It seems to me extremely unlikely that either of them will take place as planned but not the other. In modern times there have been 31 planned Summer Olympics, of which 3 (9.7%) were cancelled due to war. Including Winter Olympics gives us similar numbers, so the base rate for a Yes answer is roughly 10%. But these are already exceptional times. Sporting events (including the Tokyo Marathon) are being postponed, cancelled, or otherwise modified throughout the world. In Japan, currently, the health system is almost unable to cope (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-japan-challenges-idUSKBN2130JR)—and there are unproven concerns that Japan has been intentionally undercounting its cases. Countries around the world are restricting travel and quarantining their citizens. And at the time of writing (16 March) the world is wholly within the exponential growth phase of coronavirus spread, and it's a safe bet to say that we will see tighter and harsher restrictions in a matter of days worldwide. Doctors—in Italy and increasingly elsewhere—are speaking about having to resort to wartime triage decisions. So an alternative framing: what if we see the current circumstances _as if_ we were at war, or about to head into it? Perhaps overly dramatic (death counts much, much lower, and the sacrifices we have been asked to make are extremely modest by comparison) but such a framing helps us give less credence to the outside view. Think for example of the scenario where three or four major players—the US, Italy, France, Germany—declare they will not participate in the Olympics as planned. The pressure to postpone would be hard to resist. Or think of the planning and coordination that such a major event requires been done under self-isolation policies. Or of the qualifying trials that would need to happen worldwide, soon, when major sporting leagues are cancelling even practice sessions. It's not impossible to conceive, but it does seem quite unlikely to me. As a first stab, I'll base my forecast on two possibilities that I'll assume are independent. The Olympics will be cancelled, postponed, or relocated, if:
* that international pressure leads to it (65%), or...
* that internal pressure within Japan, either from the health system, public opinion, or from logistical challenges in the face of the pandemic, does (55%) Which leads to a likelihood of _going ahead as planned_ of 16%. I recognize those lower level estimates are ultimately guesswork, and I plan to reevaluate based on new developments on the pandemic, both globally and within Japan.

Based on the low rates of COVID-19 in India now, the theory that transmissibility in warmer climates is lower seems reasonable. If new cases in North America and Europe slow coming into late spring and early summer supporting the theory, the probability the games will be canceled will be very low. Add to that the mortality rates to the young and fit now is also very low.  I would, therefore, expect the majority of athletes will have only suffered mild symptoms if any at all if they become infected. The spectators may be a different issue, however, the majority of the money from the games comes from the broadcasters and advertisers, and not ticket sales, so limiting spectators shouldn't hurt too much. The Paralympics come later in the summer so the temperatures should still be good, and while the athletes are typically young and fit as well, there is more potential that some would suffer more from symptoms based on their underlying physical conditions. If that is widespread, a lack of athletes may disrupt the games, however, the withdrawal of up to 10% of the athletes would likely not cause the games to be canceled. Equally, a postponement would only shift the games into the cooler months, when the infections rates are expected to uptick again, therefore the only reasonable timeframe would be the summer of 2021, but the circumstances would likely be similar to now. The only difference would be the potential delivery of a vaccine, however based on the age range mortality rates, a vaccine won't make much of a difference to the athletes.

The "Home City Contract" was signed by the International Olympic Committee (IOC), the city of Tokyo and the Japanese Olympic Committee in 2013.  The contract give much leeway to the IOC to cancel (and probably to postpone and/or relocate) the Olympic Games.  The IOC has to give local organizers, the city of Tokyo and the national Olympic committee 60 days notice to cancel the games. A lot of money has been spent on the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympic games.  The appetite to postpone, cancel and/or relocate the games does not appear to be very high.  Also, the severity of the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak may decrease by June-July.  For now, the IOC is relying on the World Health Organization (WHO) for advice.  Depending on the way events unfold, I may have to change my forecast. Sources:

Let's Run Down the Options: 
1) Cancel / Postpone:  This is a non starter for strictly financial reasons.  Consider that NBC can't afford to move the games a year and be forced to refund marketing dollars.  Thus, at best they could postpone a few weeks.  Any more than a few weeks and it runs into the NFL.  However, I don't think they will view a few weeks as mattering if the pandemic has already lasted several months.  Thus, what would be gained by postponing?  Nothing. 2) Relocate:  Now this is much trickier as this is overly vague.  I wonder how "specific" they mean with "relocate."  Certain events may end up being shifted to alternate locations (this happens at the Olympics on a regular basis).  Roughly 5% of Olympics go off without any events being moved by my quick wikipedia calcs.  Is GJO going to make sure that each of the events was indeed hosted at the specific sites originally planned?  If they aren't going to count this, then at what point does it truly become "relocating" 10% of events? 20% 50%?   It's highly probable that Tokyo does not host all of the events (they already have some dozen events at hosted outside the vicinity anyhow)  I would flip my entire answer if it the allowance was provided that "relocate" means changing event venues.  If relocation only means changing the host city, then it really isn't practical. I don't see any of these options truly helping the situation. The only "real" solution which does not fall under any of the specified restrictions: 
 -> Televised Events Only:  This solution solves all of the problems and places all of the financial burden on 3rd parties (airlines/hotels). Lastly, anyone that has done any of the viral outbreak forecasts knows that there is a massive spread and then decline.  Based on the pace of transmission reported by WHO  (though honestly is probably un-reliable), my AI program resulted in a declining estimate of cases by Mid-May.  This was considerably later than what was predicted by the University of Texas: https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/2002/2002.07112.pdf

Forecast 2
My first forecast assumed that postponement was not a possibility given that no games have been postponed previously.  A recent statement by the Japanese Olympic Minister[1] has forced me to revaluate this stance.  In order to arrive at a new forecast I will take the average of the three scenarios: Not cancelled, postponed, and both cancelled (I have taken the stance that the postponement or cancellation of one but not the other should not currently be considered).  Refer to previous forecast (linked below) for discussion of factors, which I do not believe this examination will affect (at least at present time) Availability of Venues later in 2020
•	Certainly seems to be the most obvious factor and if a list of olympic venues [2] is viewed it shows that there is a good mix of existing and under construction venues; existing would suggest that they have current tenants or event schedules and under construction could mean that postponing any anticipated tenants might be possible (or not depending on what is going to happen). 
•	One example perhaps not being able to delay return to non-Olympic life: Ajinomoto Stadium which is the home of Tokyo FC, which presumably would need to take back possession.  That being said the season starts in March so perhaps no one is using it.  It is currently difficult to track down the pre-and post-Olympic planned uses of venues
•	One example of being able to delay post-Olympic life: Tokyo Tatsumi International Swimming Center: presumably outside of local swim clubs and regional competitions this wouldn’t have any marquee tenants
•	Marathons which utilize public roads lie somewhere in the middle of perhaps being possible and perhaps not being possible to postpone	 Availability of athlete accommodations and Athlete/Olympic Village
•	Olympic Village: located right beside the Athlete Village (both of which are located on pier which have been razed) does not seem to have any future tenant because all wood used to construct it will be taken down and recycled or returned to municipalities which donated the wood originally[3].  These pieces are to be used as more commemorative pieces – so no sense that they cannot wait
•	Athlete’s Village: Condos and rental units are planned of the 10,000 stand alone living spaces however, they are not planned to be made available until March 2023 [4].  Similarly to the Vancouver Winter Olympics, it stands to reason that extensive remodel or completion will be required.  As such, this seems akin to any construction delay
•	Can the athletes even be housed?  It seems the answer to this is yes.  I have assumed that no team of athletes/trainers/delegates will mind any postponement because they train 4 years for this Average weather by month and anticipated virus peak
•	Frankly this seems to be a more important factor than the two preceding because not only are the Games limited by weather (it is the summer Olympics after all). But this should be considered in conjunction with the Virus and its anticipated spread
•	Based on historical weather averages, it seems that the Games can realistically only be delayed until October (and perhaps early October at that) given the steep drop in temperature beginning in November [5] so the question becomes, will the virus be contained by that point or early enough to schedule a postponement in its logistical entirety 
•	Some public health estimates are working on the basis that infections would peak three months after first sustained community transmission [6] as astutely pointed out by @pstamp [7]
•	A three peak, could push the timeframe a bit too close to the October hard-stop for anyones comfort and making cancellation versus postponement more likely Final thoughts re postponement: 
•	This may be perhaps a stereotype, but if there is one nation that seems to understand sacrifice to achievement of societal level goals it is Japan; so it seems possible that anything that needs to be made available could be made available
•	I have assumed that no team of athletes/trainers/delegates will mind any postponement because they train 4 years for this
•	Public Health Insider’s, seem to think postponement is most likely [8] but I’m not so sure based on the factors listed above.  Logistically it may be possible, but the runway to postpone is not that long.  I think that the Japanese Olympic Decision Makers think it’s a viable option, but I don’t think that the IOC does. Keep in mind they would take input from WHO, although their statement position is that the games will continue as planned.  A public spat between the two probably wouldn’t go well for the local committee
•	Things I have not considered in great depth because I am unable to qualify in detail: broadcasting schedules.  A push to late September or early august coincides with a number of other sports and contracts to run them; that being said, would broadcasters have to pay fees in accordance with long since signed agreements and would they prefer less money from postponed games versus no ad revenue from cancelled games?  I would assume cancelled games relieves them of their financial obligations whereas postponed games do not Note: in regard to relocation, I don’t think I adequately have addressed this yet.  I do not believe that any other venue that would be acceptable to the IOC and the various Individual Nation Olympic Committees would be suitable for relocation.  Relocation within country faces the same macro factors that don’t seem to make it a plausible alternative (ie global spread of the virus) Summary of different Scenarios:
Base Rate: 10%
Inside View re Cancelation: 25%
Postponement: 35% Average of the above

We seem to be playing off medical necessity against economic interests with most of these coronavirus questions, so despite Japan's suggestion that the Olympics be postponed & the reality that the event will create an infection hotspot, I'm cautiously moving down towards the 'No' position suggested by the IOC's statement of commitment.  This move has been informed by four factors beyond those mentioned above :-  1) Japan's lack of a coronavirus stats update over the last 24hrs. Given the infection's expected trajectory, this has the appearance of political non-disclosure.  2) The seeming decision by the US and Britain to allow Covid19 to become endemic, which would make cancelling the Olympics pointless.  3)  The huge economic investment by IOC nations.  4)  The cultural adoption of a "We don't know enough about this virus to justify cancelling anything" rationale in countries making minimal attempts to contain the virus.  The more embedded that attitude becomes, the more difficult it will become for wary leaders to invoke the precautionary principle, whether it applies to national borders, international trade or major public events.

The base rate is 2%. Neither were cancelled during the Swine Flu outbreak during the 2010 Vancouver Olympics and the Zika virus at the 2016 Rio Olympics. However, a vaccine had already been produced and administered prior to the Vancouver Olympics and the Zika virus is not transmitted from human to human but via mosquitos. Therefore, qualitatively Covid-19 is different.  This is a black swan event and therefore I am not sure the historical base rate provides much use in calculating a forecast in this instance. I am going to assume that measures can be put in place to protect a relatively small number of athletes (compared to the population at large) e.g. requiring them to arrive 2 weeks in advance and self-isolating, transporting them directly to/from venues to Olympic venues.  The primary consideration therefore is crowds. For this, we need to look primarily at the number of cases in Japan. International visitors may stay away but I do not think this would cause the authorities to cancel the games considering it is so late in the day and that the games are broadcast globally (which wasn't the case in the previous instances where the games have been cancelled). We therefore need to monitor internal cases of Covid-19 in Japan and the authorities response over the next few months. This forecast will need adjusting accordingly as the circumstances are very fluid.  Additional note: there is a 2 week gap between the Olympics and Paralympics. It could be the case that the Olympics are postponed but the Paralympics are not. Indeed, the Paralympics could be extended and both could run in parallel with each other. Logistically it would be difficult but not impossible.

First of all, I think that if there is going to be a postponing, cancelation or relocation, it is going to happen with both the olympic and paralympic games. With that said, on a quick look the summer olympic games have only been canceled because of the outbreak of World Wars, which is probably one of the most extreme events in the world. During Rio Summer Olympics there was a major Zika virus epidemic and the games continued as scheduled.

I agree with @Anneinak @pstamp and others that the timeframe for this decision is short and after that it gets harder to cancel. Sounds like the decision would need to be some time in the next month or two. Given that's a political decision that involves many countries and a large multi-national non-profit I would assume the strong preference will be to kick the can down the road and make a decision later ... which means deciding to go ahead with the games. The US administration seems to be in "everything is perfectly normal" mode right now.  So I think they'll strongly prefer a plan based on mitigating risks rather than cancelling, even if the crisis gets substantially worse over the next 30 days. If it does get much worse very fast, then the most obvious risk mitigation strategy is to have fewer or no spectators. At that point I think it comes down to economics. (see: https://www.cfr.org/backgrounder/economics-hosting-olympic-games)  For the IOC it's obvious: over 90% of their revenue comes from TV and sponsorship rights which all evaporates if the games are cancelled. For Japan the host country it's cost (mostly infrastructure and security) vs income (mostly general tourism, sponsorship, TV rights and long-term value of the infrastructure and just ~10% from ticket sales). Given that the infrastructure expense is mostly already spent and tourism is likely to suck regardless, so I think economics will push them to go ahead.  If all that's true, how do we come up with a quantitative estimate? First I don't see a scenario in which just the Olympics are canceled without the Special Olympics or visa versa. I'll call those both <5%. For the other buckets I just don't know. I guess by looking at base rates for similar events. Problem: there isn't enough data for Olympics. Maybe include major world championships like swimming, track and soccer/football. The base rate for all of these is virtually zero cancellation even in the face of Zika, wars and terrorist threats. I think COVID will turn out to be on the big side of that spectrum so I'll call it 90-95% chance that they go forward. I would not be surprised to see specific countries decide not to attend or perhaps get un-invited if they have a lot of current cases.  Some other observations: 
1) Japan appears to be successful in managing their own outbreak and I assume that will continue through the spring
2) tentative consensus seems to be that even if the outbreak gets much worse, coronavirus cases are still likely to drop off as northern hemisphere weather warms so hopefully the trend will be strongly down by the time May and June get here

Over time, as the origin, mode of transmission, rate of infection, etc for zika became better known and pre-cautionary and preventative steps were identified, fears subsided and the games were not cancelled.  I assume that the same will be true with this, however, at this point, COVID-19 seems to be far easier to get than zika, and far harder to take precautions against. The Olympics involves many mass gatherings and lots of international travel, the two worst things in a pandemic.  The virus may have slowed down somewhat in China, but it still has most of the world's population to infect. Most of the world is still waiting for the real outbreak to begin. There is therefore a very good chance that it will still be spreading in a large part of the world by end of May (the end of their current wait-and-see period).  Even if it's mostly subsided by then, there will still be a significant chance that it will come back (cf. the "deadly second wave" of the Spanish flu). Given that risk, even if Japan and the IOC want to go ahead with it, many countries may choose not to participate, which would force Japan and the IOC to cancel anyway. There is also the disruption to training. Training in many events involves the gathering of many people: teammates, training partners, coaches, trainers, etc. With traveling substantially reduced and mass gatherings discouraged or prohibited, regular training sessions will be difficult to carry out. Even if they are logistically possible, some participants may decide to postpone training, for fear of getting sick. This is not to mention that many participants actually will get infected. Though the death rate is low for most athletes who are younger, they will nevertheless have to be quarantined while they are sick. However, there is immense pressure to carry on with the Games nonetheless. A lot of money is riding on it. Perhaps organizers will decide on some scaled-down version of the Games, with fewer spectators. And if the pandemic starts to subside in May for some unknown reason, perhaps organizers will take the risk of a second wave, and carry on anyway. Finally, I see no reason why one of the Games would be canceled, but not the other. But I'll leave 2% as a hedge for any blind spots.

IMHO, the main problem now is not Japan or China, or S. Korea as these ones are getting a hold of their respective epidemics/outbreaks. The same goes for South East Asia. If the preventive measures hold, COVID-19 may be on the background, but not enough to prevent the Games. Plus the Japanese have capabilities to screen.  The main problem is Iran, which clearly underestimates number of infections. And the Middle East. But they do not rule IOC. Also, COVID-19 may be seasonal. Hence, by May it may well be over for the Northern hemisphere. Add to this that by that time a vaccine(s) may be available plus more effective treatments. There is a possibility that SARS-CoV-2 may mutate and become more dangerous (though it can go the opposite way as well). But so far there is no evidence of that happening. My opinion. Do not pretend to have a crystal ball. I may reconsider later based on future developments.
